ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Respondent
How many times does your child get out of the house per week for activities other than school (e.g., sports, extracurricular activities, activities with the family)?
About how many books does your child have?
When your child was under the age of five, about how many times per week did you read to them?
How many times per month do you take your child on errands with you outside the house?
Do you believe that parents should usually or always spend time teaching their kids?
How many meals do you eat with your child each day?
How many times has your child been spanked in the past week?
Does your family subscribe to at least one magazine?
Does your child have access to music?
Did you and/or your partner teach your child numbers at home?
Did you and/or your partner teach your child the alphabet at home?
Did you and/or your partner teach your child colors at home?
Did you and/or your partner teach your child shapes and sizes at home?
Does your child have a choice about the foods they eat for breakfast and lunch?
Is the TV on less than 5 hours per day in your home?
Have you taken your child to a museum in the past year?
Is your child expected to make his/her bed?
Is your child expected to clean his/her own room?
Is your child expected to clean up after they spill something?
Is your child expected to pick up after themselves?
Is your child expected to keep shared living areas clean?
Is your child expected to do chores such as mow the lawn, help with dinner, or do the dishes?
Is your child expected to help manage his or her own time?
Is there a musical instrument in your home that your child can use?
Does your family receive a daily newspaper?
How many times a week does your child read for enjoyment?
Do you and your partner encourage your child to have hobbies?
Is your child involved with any sports, music, art, dance, or drama organizations?
Has your child been taken to a musical or drama performance in the past year?
Does your family visit with other family or friends at least 2-3 times per month?
How many times per week does your child spend time with their father?
How often does your child participate in outdoor activities with their father (per week)?
Do you discuss television programs with your child when watching TV?
How often does a caregiver take your child far from home?
When you are busy with housework, do you try to engage your child in what you are doing (e.g., talking with him/her about what you are doing or asking questions about what you are doing)?
Did you show or teach your child something new this past week, like teach a new word, or help child do something difficult?
Please show me what your child typically plays with on his/her own. Gross motor objects available (e.g., ball, rope, ring, stone).
Please show me what your child typically plays with on his/her own. Push or pull toys available (e.g., pull with string, push box).
Please show me what your child typically plays with on his/her own. Cuddly toys available?
Please show me what your child typically plays with on his/her own. Simple eye-hand coordination materials available (e.g. single object that rattles, shakes, squeezes).
Please show me what your child typically plays with on his/her own. Complex eye-hand coordination materials available (e.g., different shaped blocks, pencil and paper).
Please show me what your child typically plays with on his/her own. Book or item that has both pictures and words together (not textbook, can be collection of pictures).
Please show me what your child typically plays with on his/her own. At least 1 adult book or magazine is observed in the home (includes religious books but not textbooks).
Do you provide materials or activities that are slightly difficult for your child?
Does your child have access to childrens books?
Are there any objects that the child plays with to create a story, play pretend, or imitate actions he/she sees in the home/community?
Does your child play any structured games with people (e.g., circle games, clapping/singing games)?
Does your child know where to find his/her playthings (e.g, bag, box)?
Have you ever found/made/ gotten something new for your child to play with?
When did you get the newest toy/object?
In the past week, did you look or someone in the household look at pictures in a book, calendar or magazine with the child?
How often do you tell stories or sing songs with your child?
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) After visitor praises child, mother responds positively (e.g. mother nods, smiles, thanks, agrees).
Do you receive guests at home or visit family?
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) The mother spontaneously talks to the child.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) The mother responds verbally to childs talk or gestures (does not ignore the child; do not include scolding or shouting).
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother tells child the name of an object or person during visit.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mothers speech is distinct, clear, and audible.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother talks well and freely to the interviewer.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother permits child to play freely (includes messy, noisy play).
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother spontaneously praises child verbally without prompt at least twice. FIRST INSTANCE
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother spontaneously praises child verbally without prompt at least twice. SECOND INSTANCE
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother conveys positive feelings towards child. For example: smiling, tone of voice, or using positive words
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother caresses, strokes head, or kisses the child.
Does your child usually eat supper or any meal with the whole family?
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother makes effort to provide child with a play object during visit.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother shouts at child during the visit (except for corrective shouting to stop a child from doing something dangerous).
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother complains about child or says child is bad.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother hits, pushes, shakes child during visit.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother threatens the child with punishment during visit.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother restricts or interferes with childs activity during visit three or more times. FIRST INSTANCE
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother restricts or interferes with childs activity during visit three or more times. SECOND INSTANCE
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother restricts or interferes with childs activity during visit three or more times. THIRD INSTANCE
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Observe whether indoor/outdoor area is safe for play.
(Reaction/Emotion after prompt) Mother keeps child within eyesight, looks at him/her often.
Does the father of the child spend some time every day caring for the child?
When you are away, how many other people/caregivers are available to look after the child?
Does your child have regular playmates that are around his/her same age?
How often does your child go to the market with you or another member of the household?
How often does your child go out of the house/yard?
